Event.name: Colonization
Event.definition:
<def-root>A group of <fen>Colonists</fen> from a <fen>Homeland</fen> migrate to and proceed to settle in a <fen>New_area</fen>. The <fen>New_area</fen> then becomes their permanent home. The <fen>New_area</fen> and <fen>Homeland</fen> are in some way construed as being part of the same organization or system. In the case of (people from) nation-states colonizing other areas, the colony and nation-state are considered a single political entity. In the extended sense of living things in general colonizing or settling a new area, the original <fen>Homeland</fen> must still inhabited by some of the same group. In this sense Colonization is distinct from migration or exodus.
<ex><fex name="tim">In the 7th century BC</fex>, <fex name="col">Phoenicians</fex> <t>colonized</t> <fex name="new">the eastern section of Libya</fex>.</ex> <ex>In the 7th century BC, <fex name="hom">Phoenicians</fex> <t>colonized</t> the eastern section of Libya.</ex> <ex><fex name="col">Finns</fex> <t>colonized</t> <fex name="new">the land</fex> from the south <fex name="tim">some 2,000 to 4,000 years ago</fex></ex> <ex>If a <t>colony</t> <fex name="new">from Britain</fex> was established in that large tract of Country, and if we were at war with Holland or Spain, we might very powerfully annoy either state from our new settlement.</ex>
This frame also includes metaphorical uses involving animals or plants, or abstract domains such as ideas.
<ex><fex name="col">Deciduous trees such as red alder</fex> <fex name="tim">subsequently</fex> <t>colonized</t> <fex name="new">the logged area</fex>.</ex>
<ex>Conservatives don't get what the left gets, which is that <fex name="col">the left</fex> has <fex name="tim">already</fex> <t>colonized</t> and converted <fex name="new">whole university departments</fex>.</ex>
<ex>As the years progressed and adaptations occurred <fex name="col">new species and subspecies</fex> began to <t>populate</t> <fex name="hom">the islands</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Colonists
Arg.definition:
<def-root>A group of people who move together to an area outside their <fen>Homeland</fen> for the purpose of settling.
<ex><fex name="col">Spain</fex> <t>settled</t> the northern areas of Mexico through the use of missions, civil settlements, and presidios. </ex>
Often the phrase expressing the <fen>Colonists</fen> will also encode the <fen>Homeland</fen> (e.g., <ment>French people</ment>, <ment>China</ment>), which we indicate with second-layer FE annotation.
<ex>In the 7th century BC, <fex name="col">Phoenicians</fex> <t>colonized</t> the eastern section of Libya.</ex> <ex>In the 7th century BC, <fex name="hom">Phoenicians</fex> <t>colonized</t> the eastern section of Libya</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Homeland
Arg.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Homeland</fen> is where the <fen>Colonists</fen> are originally from.</def-root>

Arg.name: New_area
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Colonists</fen> move to the <fen>New_area</fen>, inhabiting it and (in the case of nation-states) extending the control of the <fen>Homeland</fen>.
<ex>Norse invaders in the 900s <t>colonized</t> <fex name="new">the North Midlands</fex> more densely than any other part of England" </ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Time
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The time at which the colonizing takes place.
<ex>The English <t>colonized</t> the islands <fex name="tim">in 1632</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Degree
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The extent to which the group of <fen>Colonists</fen> spreads across or inhabits the <fen>New_area</fen>.
<ex>In the reign of Elizabeth, the English strove to <fex name="deg">thoroughly</fex> <t>colonize</t> Ireland, which they had originally invaded in the twelfth century.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Purpose
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The purpose for which the colonizing is done.
<ex>Humans in the future may end up <t>colonizing</t> outer space <fex name="pur">in order to survive</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Explanation
Arg.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Explanation</fen> denotes a proposition from which the colonization event logically follows.</def-root>

lexUnit.name: colonize.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: extend the territory of a nation-state (or other system) by establishing other land as an area for settlement.

lexUnit.name: colonist.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a settler in or inhabitant of a colony.

lexUnit.name: colony.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a country or area under the political control of another country and occupied by settlers from that country.

lexUnit.name: settle.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: (for a nation-state, or members thereof) go to a new area to live.

lexUnit.name: settlement [act].n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the action or process of settling.

lexUnit.name: settlement [entity].n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a place where colonists establish a community

lexUnit.name: settler.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a person who settles in an area, especially one with no or few previous inhabitants.

lexUnit.name: populate.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: form the population of (a place).

lexUnit.name: repopulate.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to grow a population again in an area after previous population that decreased or dispersed.
